titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Experiment Station Publications Photographic Collection 1949-1979
Oregon State University Experiment Station Publications Photographic Collection
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Elizabeth Nielsen.
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

publicationstmt.publisher: Oregon State University Libraries, University Archives

repository.corpname: Oregon State University Libraries, Special Collections & Archives Research Center

origination.corpname: Oregon State University. Agricultural Experiment Station.

did.unittitle: Experiment Station Publications Photographic Collection
did.abstract: The Experiment Station Publications Photographic Collection document Agricultural Experiment Station research in Corvallis and at Branch Stations throughout Oregon.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographs of Station research both in Corvallis and at Branch Stations throughout Oregon. Subjects include Station personnel; Branch station and campus buildings and research facilities; and research projects in agricultural chemistry, agricultural engineering, animal sciences, dairy husbandry, entomology, crop and soil science, fisheries and wildlife, food technology, horticulture, irrigation, microbiology, nutrition, poultry science, and vegetable crops.

Many of the photographs were taken by Robert Birdsall, Agricultural Information Specialist (1952-1963) and later Journalism Department faculty (1963-1983). Other photographers include Bob Mason, Bill Reasons, and Len Calvert.

This collection consists almost exclusively of b/w contact prints and camera negatives (4x5 and 120). The contact prints are glued to 6x9 in. cards. There are also a few b/w 8x10 prints without camera negatives (P132:237-238) and several color prints and negatives (P132:239-241). One negative (P132:054) has been removed from the collection because of excessive buckling of the emulsion.

arrangement.p: All of the images have been assigned individual item numbers (P132:1-P132:241). The bulk of the images are grouped by general subject as shown on the inventory.

prefercite.p: Experiment Station Publications Photographic Collection (P 132), Oregon State University Archives, Corvallis, Oregon.

relatedmaterial.p: Many other photographs of Agricultural Experiment Station programs are part of the Agricultural Experiment Station (P 29), Agricultural Communications (P 120), and Station Bulletin Illustrations (P 19) Photographic Collections.

controlaccess.corpname: Oregon State College. Agricultural Experiment Station

separatedmaterial.p: Negative 472E removed from collection due to excessive buckling of the emulsion.

did.unittitle: Agricultural Engineering
Glen Page, OSC agricultural engineer, examines new soil fumigation blade he developed
Kink pipe before Dale Kirk, Agricultural Engineer, applies water pressure from hydraulic pump
Te May Ching at work in seed lab; taken by Len Calvert

Experimental model: machine using vibration to achieve partial separation of seed samples. From left: Byron Mikkelson, Assistant in Ag. Engineering; Dr. Oren Justice, research botanist in Field Crops and Animal Science branch; and Ed Hardin, seed technologist; taken by Calvert
D.E. Booster, OSC Agricultural Engineer, demonstrating electrostatic seed separator that employs differences in conductivity of seeds as a basis for separation; taken by R. Birdsall
Gladiolus harvester developed by Myron Cropsey
Gladiolus harvester developed by Myron Cropsey
Cutting daily green chop for dairy feed

Picking pears from a mechanical self-propelled "Girette"near Medford. Hoist arm is controlled from the picker's tower and swings from tree to unloading station where bag is dumped; taken by Don Langmo
Experimental blackberry harvester being tested in Marion county; taken by Birdsall
Fence building at the Henry Klages farm, Joseph, Oregon
Branch Stations
Ranchers listen to station personnel explain range management programs at Squaw Butte Experiment Station
Robert J. Raleigh begins field day by explaining program
Squaw Butte and station building of Squaw Butte Experiment Station
Various views of Squaw Butte. Some showing improved range, others showing station herd grazing
View of Squaw Butte range
Burns Post Office (headquarters of Squaw Butte Experiment Station)
Experimental greenhouse, plastic, under trial at North Willamette Experiment Station at Aurora; taken by Bob Mason
Field Day, Umatilla Branch Station
Harold White, Superintendent of Southern Oregon Branch Station, examines certified talent alfalfa being grown in tent. Seed is from pure stock of talent alfalfa. The tent is used to maintain purity
Art Sawyer, Superintendent, examines crested wheat grass seedings at Squaw Butte-Harney Branch Station
Merril Oveson, Superintendent of Pendleton Branch Station, examines safflower on the station grounds
Malheur branch experiment station visitors watch Albert S. Hunter, OSC soils scientist, demonstrate combine designed to harvest experimental grain plots; taken by R. Birdsall
Malcom Johnson, Superintendent of Central Oregon Experiment Station
Gene Cross tells about research on barley and wheat plots at the station. The woman is the county commissioner
Superintendent Charles Rohde of the Pendleton Experiment Station
Fred Hagelstein (left) talks with Superintendent Charles Rohde. In background is G.Burton Wood
G. Burton Wood talks with resident before outdoor meeting on lawn of station
Box lunches keep Chamber of Commerce group busy during tour of station facilities
M.W. Mellenthin with limb cage developed to control temperature
Administration building at Station
Walt Mellenthin, Superintendent
Field Day at North Willamette branch station; taken by Birdsall

Pear breeding experiments at the Southern Oregon Branch Experiment Station are aimed at improving pear varieties. A tree has been completely covered to insure controlled breeding work. Seedling produced from see on this tree are resistant to blight and make excellent rootstocks. Bees are kept in enclosure for pollinating. They transfer pollen from a bouquet of flowers of another variety
General shot of beef feeding lots at Umatilla branch station; taken by Birdsall
Vegetable Crops
William Allan Frazier, horticulturist, examines blue lake type bush beans he has developed; taken by Mason
William Allan Frazier, horticulturist, examines blue lake pole bean parent he is using in genetic work; taken by Mason

William Allan Frazier, horticulturist, developed high quality bush bean through eight backcrosses to famed Blue Lake pole bean. Result: tender, stringless pods yielding 4 to 5 tons per acre and well-adapted to machine picking; taken by R. Birdsall
William Allan Frazier, horticulturist, examines early hybrid tomatoes on left, compared with Stokesdales on right
Mechanical harvesting on Wiley Clowers farm. Potatoes on ground are undersized taken out by eliminators
Mechanical transfer from sacks to bulk-bed on Harold Allen farm
Close-up of mechanical harvester
Digger and harvester working together

Mechanical bush bean harvester covers 3 1/2 to 5 acres a day, travels between three-fourths to one mile an hour, and picks 15 to 20 tons a day. Tested this year by Oregon State College, the machine proved 70 to 85 percent efficient in harvesting new Blue Lake hybrid bush beans on OSC experimental plots near Corvallis; taken by R. Birdsall
Mechanical harvester being tested on onions in Malheur County
Propane burning of potato vines for easier harvest and for Verticillium Wilt control at Harold Allen farm
Landscapes
View of Harvey Aluminum plant, The Dalles
Entering the Fort Rock Valley form the south
Snow drifts in the Fort Rock Valley
View of Fort Rock by way of Rube Long's mail box
Typical view of Fort Rock area
View of Hood River Valley from Mid-Columbia Branch Station
View of John Day valley from U.S. Highway 395 between John Day and Pendleton
Band belonging to Ralph Longfellow is on a long journey from the Snake River to summer range in the high Wallowas, Joseph, Oregon; taken by Walter W. Klages
View of Harney valley from the foot hills of Steen's Mountain
Entomology
Entomologist William P. Nagel examines sample of damaged bark. Damage inflicted by the Douglas-fir beetle
Peter Westigard, entomologist, check codling moth trap to determine population in test block of pears
OSU entomologist Knud Swenson examines artificially reared aphid colonies

As a marked bee leaves the feeding station, Dr. Edward Anderson, an entomologist from Eastern Oregon College, calls Schricker by walkie talkie and punches his stop watch. Wind direction and velocity are read from the anometer shown at left. Wind is figured to compute the air distance travelled by the bee; taken by Don Wright

Dr. Schricker clocks the bee's return trip to a specially built observational hive. Progressively higher doses of the insecticide, parathion, slows the bee's normal flying speed of above 20 m.p.h. and disrupts an intricate dance which the bees use to communicate distance and direction to food; taken by Don Wright

A honey bee lands at a feeding station to take on a load of sugar solution containing a trace of insecticide. As she sucks up the artificial nectar she will be marked with colored dots to allow the scientists to observe her behavior back at the hive; taken by Don Wright
Station for leafcutter bees at Malheur station; taken by Birdsall
Portable bed for alkali bees at Malheur station; taken by Birdsall
Close up of a bee hive; taken by Stephens
Earl Brown, county agent at Milton-Freewater spraying cattle with DDT; taken by Goulding
Backrubbers for insecticide applications for cattle; taken by Goulding
"Pour-on" treatments can be used either for a single steer or in a sarge feedlot/cattle-grub control
Food Technology
Dr. Harold Schultz, head of Food Technology at OSC, examines some dehydrated potatoes at the OSC Food Technology lab
Dr. Harold Schultz examines some hamburger that has been irradiated to kill all bacteria. Cans are stored at 100 degree rooms to test storage quality
Dr. Robert F.Cain putting ground hamburger into cans before being sent for irradiation
Dr. Wiegand, left, and Dr. Thomas Onsdorff, right, examine dehydrated onion rings
Processing blue lake beans at Blue Lake Packers, Corvallis
Microbiology
Roy Wilfred Stein and Paul R. Elliker remove raw milk samples from incubator and will next test them for numbers of bacteria
Roy Wilfred Stein and William E. Sandine, junior bacteriologist, transfer raw milk to a petri dish where milk will be sealed and incubated
Agricultural Chemistry

Virgil Freed, OSC agricultural chemist, measures the surface tension of an experiment spray solution with a tensiometer. Tensiometer is used to measure effectiveness of various wetting agents mixed with chemical sprays; taken by Mason
Agricultural chemist, Virgil Freed, seeking ways to utilize wastes
Dr. Joseph Butts, head of Agricultural Chemistry, adjusts the high vacuum system used to make materials radioactive
Using radioactive materials in fundamental research with corn pollination are J. Ritchie Cowan, assistant agronomist (left), and Dr. J.S. Butts, biochemist in charge
Poultry Science
White leghorn rooster which genetically carries disease resistance plus high egg production. Part of Paul Bernier's survival flock; taken by Reasons

Rooster-hen ratio requirements are being studied at the college. This pen of birds is being used in the trials. As few as 6 or 7 roosters per 100 hens have been found satisfactory for consistent high fertility

Effect of unidentified nutrients, probably vitamins, on chick growth is shown here. Chick at right has been fed normal growing diet supplemented with dried egg yolk. Chick at left has been fed only usual diet; taken by Mason
One of 200 white leghorn families used in selecting disease resistant birds. Part of Paul Bernier's experimental survival flock; taken by Bill Reasons
The value of "open-air" poultry houses is being studied by the Experiment Station. They show real promise for the Willamette Valley in early trials
Dr. Paul E. Bernier demonstrates measurement techniques used in chicken breeding research
Tom turkey at the OSC experimental turkey farm
View of OSC turkey flock; taken by Bill Reasons
Cornelius Bateson and Praetum broiler
Tests on hatchability. Newly hatched tray of chicks held by Ben Kladder (Dryden Hall janitor and maintenance person, especially boiler room maintenance)
Dr. J.E. Parker and rooster with dubbed comb
George Arscott shown weighing broilers fed high energy rations
George Arscott examines broilers fed comparative ration of Oregon (right) or Midwest corn
Dr. Paul Bernier, OSC poultry researcher, examines hybrid rooster containing lethal gene
Dr. Paul Bernier holding roosters developed by two hybrid lines. White leghorn at left has lethal gene and its chicks will never live if sired by this rooster. Normal rooster is on right
Dr. Paul Bernier examines white leghorn rooster which genetically carries disease resistance plus high egg production; taken by Bill Reasons
Dr. Paul Bernier examines hen from one of his survival flock experiments; taken by Bill Reasons
Dairy Husbandry
Making cheese at the OSC dairy plant
Making butter at the OSC dairy plant
View of OSC dairy barn
Fisheries and Wildlife
Student examining trap for insects, algae, etc. located in Berry Creek. Picture used for cover of "Oregon's Agricultural Progress," winter issue, 1960
Student using dip net in Berry Creek, an experimental 2creek located on Adair tract
Beet juice being dumped into Willamette River near Eugene; taken by Bill Reasons
Stream pollution in Willamette River near Eugene; taken by Bill Reasons
Graduate student Floyd Hutchins feeds young coho in test of growth ability
OSU researcher Dean Lee Shumway checks fish swimming ability in water of varying oxygen concentration which is pumped through tubes at varying velocity
Carl Bond catching a 12-inch trout
Charles Warren, OSC fisheries biologist, examines artificial stream before production of kraft paper mill wastes at OSC fisheries laboratory; taken by B. Reasons
Arrowtoothed sole or turbot. Proved to be an excellent growth promoter for mink
Black Rockfish, proved excellent to use in mink diet as promoter of dark fur color
Meadow Mice. See "Oregon's Agricultural Progress" winter 1960 issue
Finding out how moles live is paying off in control of this animal
Pheasants; taken by Mason
Pheasant cock; taken by Mason
Animal Sciences
Experimental mink
Natural rank mink from OSC fur farm
View of OSC sheep on hill pasture
Idwal Ralph Jones, dairy scientist, offers new hay wafer to dairy cow in OSC trials comparing the wafer with standard alfalfa pellets; taken by R. Birdsall
Part of Squaw Butte-Harney range herd
Hereford cattle in Texas; taken by Jack Miller
Home Economics

Test patients are on control diets for 30 days to determine vitamin needs for human subjects. From left, (facing camera) Margaret Fincke, Clara Storvick, Nina Morley, and Betty Hawthorne (back to camera); taken by Mason
Food Technology
Finding a wide variety of tasteful, wholesome foods at the supermarket
Animal Sciences
Bob Chestnutt, graduate student, puts arm in clear up to shoulder when removing cud from rumen
Bob Chestnutt, graduate student, examines cud taken from cow's rumen
Fisheries and Wildlife
Oyster larva clinging to glass slide growing as artificial seed at Yaquina Bay
Pesticides, Herbicides, and Insecticides
Tansy Ragwort infested with cinnabar moth
Burning English rye grass stubble to prevent blind seed disease. E.G. Mason farm, Jefferson, Oregon
Gorse growing on beach near Bandon
Soils
Sample of soil erosion in Columbia Basin taken just north of the town of Moro
Erosion on Columbia Basin wheatlands
Pesticides, Herbicides, and Insecticides
Crop dusting of chemical sprays control weeds in seeds and grain
Crops and Irrigation
Luther Fitch and experimental stand of Lenore flax at Malheur station where it was seeding in mid-March. This is a fall-seeded crop in Willamette Valley; taken by Birdsall
Sprinklers at work in orchard at the Hood River branch experiment station
Water/Irrigation
Natural flooding of meadows in late spring was used by early settlers
View of overhead sprinkling designed for corn irrigation experiments at East farm
Use of small plot irrigator on sweet corn at vegetable crop farm, Corvallis; taken by Harry Mack
Luther Fitch setting siphon tubes on onion plots at Malheur station; taken by Birdsall
Crops
Mint under irrigation between Madras and Redmond
Harvesting barley at E.G. Mason farm, Jefferson, Oregon; taken by Mason
Alfalfa seed being harvested in Umatilla county; taken by Bill Stephen
Stacking hay loose has proved faster and more economical on the Henry Klages and Sons ranch, Joseph, where feeding is done near the haystack
Alfalfa and grass hay in windrows ready to be stacked. Henry Klages and Sons ranch, Joseph
Seed bed preparation with a D-2 Caterpillar and Van Brunt cultivator. Bill Cool farm, Joseph
Hay is transported by trucks and farmhand to a feed lot. Henry Klages and Sons ranch, Joseph
J. Ritchie Cowan in forage breeding plots at Hyslop farm; taken by Birdsall
Agronomist Rod Frakes examines alfalfa flower being used for breeding; used in Oregon's Agricultural Progress
Winter safflower being tested at Pendleton station by Laurn Beutler; taken by R. Birdsall
Charles Rohde (left) and President Jensen examine stripe rust resistant Omar during Pendleton Station 1963 Field Day; taken by R. Birdsall
Horticulture

Linda Clement, 5, and Charles Ruettgers, 4, of Scio, were among 2000 visitors from throughout the Northwest who visited the 1953 annual Oregon Early Chrysanthemum Show and Field Day at Corvallis, October 3-4; taken by R. Birdsall
Dr. David Chilcote, head of straw utilization project, hods cubes of perennial ryegrass straw for experiments
Walt Mellenthin at Lewis Brown farm with dwarf apple plantings
Elmer Hansen, OSC Horticulturist, examines carbon dioxide level as being piped onto polyethylene bags to find out what causes brown core in pears; taken by Mason
Elmer Hansen and lab apparatus which detects amounts of various acids present in stored pears. See story in "Oregon's Agricultural Progress"

Jesse E. Harmond makes flax movies while his flax tour visitors look on. From left to right: Harmond (at the projector),; Leonard Klein, Agricultural Engineer; Fred Shideler, head of Journalism; F.A. Gilfillan, Dean of Science; Norville R. Gish, assistant experiment station editor; extreme right man unidentified
Henry Harman, OSC Horticulturalist, examines Golden Doyenner pears, on of the tested varieties he thinks adapted for commercial trial; taken by Mason
Vera Jorgenson of Corvallis picking apples; taken by Bill Reasons
Crops
Wilson Foote, OSC Agronomist, removes anthers from inbred barleys in preparation for crossing with other lines. Taken at Granger
Mr. Harry August Schoth standing in the original planting of Alta Fescue on the Oregon Agricultural Experiment Station, Corvallis, Oregon

Application of 80 pounds nitrogen fertilizer (actual N) per acre on test plots of Elgin winter wheat at Malheur branch experiment station will yield estimated 60 bushels per acre on plot at left compared to 30 bushels for unfertilized plot at right. Station superintendent Neil Hoffman says recent mild winters have increased interest among local farmers in winter wheat. Year's work load is distributed by seeding in the fall rather than during busy spring season; taken by Birdsall
Ralph Garren counting strawberry leaves taken from plants treated with radioactive Maleic Hydrazide
OSU Horticulturist Harry John Mack examines a test planting of broccoli
Unidentified harvest scene
Harvesting an unknown crop
Flax field binder-loader in action near Mt. Angel. Developed by flax research engineers
New push type flax puller which shows promise of substantial savings to the fiber flax industry
Cuber, on Hyslop farm. Leased for two years for straw utilization project. Machine used to cube ryegrass straw for experiments
View of new OSC greenhouses
Visitors viewing the OSC mum farm
Hyslop Farm: Wilson Foote, Al Meyers, Roy Ward looking at Abruzzi rye
Wilson Foote at Hyslop Farm
Strawberry Pickers Wanted signs used in Strawberries for Tomorrow film about mechanical harvesting of strawberries
